questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : ENGLISH I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "QUALIFIER LEVEL : ENGLISH I (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"

questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:

Many great inventions are greeted with ridicule and disbelief. The invention of the airplane was no exception. Although many people who heard about the first powered flight on December 17, 1903, were excited and impressed, others reacted with peals of laughter. The idea of flying an aircraft was repulsive to some people. Such people called Wilbur and Orville Wright, the inventors of the first flying machine, impulsive fools. Negative reactions, however, did not stop the Wrights. Impelled by their desire to succeed, they continued their experiments in aviation. Orville and Wilbur Wright had always had a compelling interest in aeronautics and mechanics. As young boys they earned money by making and selling kites and mechanical toys. Later, they designed a newspaper-folding machine, built a printing press, and operated a bicycle-repair shop. In 1896, when they read about the death of Otto Lilienthal, the brother's interest in flight grew into a compulsion. Lilienthal, a pioneer in hang-gliding, had controlled his gliders by shifting his body in the desired direction. This idea was repellent to the Wright brothers, however, and they searched for more efficient methods to control the balance of airborne vehicles. In 1900 and 1901, the Wrights tested numerous gliders and developed control techniques. The brothers' inability to obtain enough lift power for the gliders almost led them to abandon their efforts. After further study, the Wright brothers concluded that the published tables of air pressure on curved surfaces must be wrong. They set up a wind tunnel and began a series of experiments with model wings. Because of their efforts, the old tables were repealed in time and replaced by the first reliable figures for air pressure on curved surfaces. This work, in turn, made it possible for them to design a machine that would fly. In 1903 the Wrights built their first airplane, which cost less than one thousand dollars. The Wright brothers were the first to build a full-size machine that could fly under its own power. As the contributors of one of the most outstanding engineering achievements in history, the Wright brothers are accurately called the fathers of aviation.

questions.question_text_1: How did Lilienthal control his gliders?
question_texts: How did Lilienthal control his gliders?

options.option_text: With the support of a powered engine
With the support of wind energy
By shifting his body in the desired direction
By using an aeroplane to shift it to the desired direction

In 1896, when they read about the death of Otto Lilienthal, the brother's interest in flight grew into a compulsion. Lilienthal, a pioneer in hang-gliding, had controlled his gliders by shifting his body in the desired direction. This idea was repellent to the Wright brothers, however, and they searched for more efficient methods to control the balance of airborne vehicles. In 1900 and 1901, the Wrights tested numerous gliders and developed control techniques. The brothers' inability to obtain enough lift power for the gliders almost led them to abandon their efforts. After further study, the Wright brothers concluded that the published tables of air pressure on curved surfaces must be wrong. They set up a wind tunnel and began a series of experiments with model wings. Because of their efforts, the old tables were repealed in time and replaced by the first reliable figures for air pressure on curved surfaces. This work, in turn, made it possible for them to design a machine that would fly. In 1903 the Wrights built their first airplane, which cost less than one thousand dollars. The Wright brothers were the first to build a full-size machine that could fly under its own power. As the contributors of one of the most outstanding engineering achievements in history, the Wright brothers are accurately called the fathers of aviation.

questions.question_text_1: What was the reason behind their inability to obtain enough lift power for the gliders?
question_texts: What was the reason behind their inability to obtain enough lift power for the gliders?

options.option_text: Wrong values in the published tables of air pressure on curved surfaces
High air pressure on flat surfaces
Steeply curved surfaces and lack of access to equipment

parent_question.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions:

Many great inventions are greeted with ridicule and disbelief. The invention of the airplane was no exception. Although many people who heard about the first powered flight on December 17, 1903, were excited and impressed, others reacted with peals of laughter. The idea of flying an aircraft was repulsive to some people. Such people called Wilbur and Orville Wright, the inventors of the first flying machine, impulsive fools. Negative reactions, however, did not stop the Wrights. Impelled by their desire to succeed, they continued their experiments in aviation. Orville and Wilbur Wright had always had a compelling interest in aeronautics and mechanics. As young boys they earned money by making and selling kites and mechanical toys. Later, they designed a newspaper-folding machine, built a printing press, and operated a bicycle-repair shop. In 1896, when they read about the death of Otto Lilienthal, the brother's interest in flight grew into a compulsion. Lilienthal, a pioneer in hang-gliding, had controlled his gliders by shifting his body in the desired direction. This idea was repellent to the Wright brothers, however, and they searched for more efficient methods to control the balance of airborne vehicles. In 1900 and 1901, the Wrights tested numerous gliders and developed control techniques. The brothers' inability to obtain enough lift power for the gliders almost led them to abandon their efforts. After further study, the Wright brothers concluded that the published tables of air pressure on curved surfaces must be wrong. They set up a wind tunnel and began a series of experiments with model wings. Because of their efforts, the old tables were repealed in time and replaced by the first reliable figures for air pressure on curved surfaces. This work, in turn, made it possible for them to design a machine that would fly. In 1903 the Wrights built their first airplane, which cost less than one thousand dollars. The Wright brothers were the first to build a full-size machine that could fly under its own power. As the contributors of one of the most outstanding engineering achievements in history, the Wright brothers are accurately called the fathers of aviation.

questions.question_text_1: Read the following telephonic conversation and fill in the blanks with appropriate responses in the given subquestions. Arun: Good morning Ms.Girija! Class Teacher: Good morning! (i)_________________ Arun: I am Arun Srinivasan. I am the class monitor of the class of which you are the class teacher, 6E. Class Teacher: Oh yes, Arun! I could not recognise your voice. The audio (ii) ____________ Arun: Is the audio better now, ma’am? Class Teacher: Yes yes, tell me. (iii) _________________ Arun: Ma’am, I wanted to check your availability for scheduling the PTA meeting. (iv) __________ the slot from 2 PM, on the 28th of this month? Class Teacher: Let me check my schedule… Yes, I am free in that slot. You can confirm it. Arun: Thanks a lot, ma’am. I will schedule the meeting for that slot and send out an email to the class. Class Teacher: Sure, go ahead. (v) ______________ Arun? Arun: No ma’am. Thanks for your time! Class Teacher: You are welcome, Arun. See you on Monday.

Class Teacher: Sure, go ahead. (v) ______________ Arun? Arun: No ma’am. Thanks for your time! Class Teacher: You are welcome, Arun. See you on Monday.

questions.question_text_1: Fill in the blanks with the appropriate option. The meaning of the phrasal verb ‘rule out ’ is _____________.
question_texts: Fill in the blanks with the appropriate option. The meaning of the phrasal verb ‘rule out ’ is _____________.

options.option_text: To lose consciousness due to dehydration
To rule longer than any other monarch
To put out a fire by stomping over it

questions.question_text_1: Select true or false for the following statement. The idiom ‘to hear on the grapevine’ means ‘to hear a rumour or an unconfirmed story.’
question_texts: Select true or false for the following statement. The idiom ‘to hear on the grapevine’ means ‘to hear a rumour or an unconfirmed story.’

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following sentences makes use of a phrase that means “to be difficult to understand”? Focus on the underlined parts of the sentence.

options.option_text: I was trying to comprehend her speech, but I zoned out.
This Maths textbook is all Greek to me.
This hieroglyph, while cryptic at an advanced level, can be cracked with theright technique.
She is a very difficult person – she even snitched on our team.

question_texts: Identify the underlined part of the sentence. Ramya can literally live on fish tacos.

question_texts: ‘I can’t swim’. ‘Can’t ’ here denotes ____.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Qualifier Level: English I (Computer-Based Exam)"** based on the provided question paper.
The exam focuses on **vocabulary, grammar, reading comprehension, phonetics, and communication skills**.

---

### **1. Vocabulary & Synonyms**
#### **Core Concepts:**
- **Synonyms/Antonyms**: Matching words with similar or opposite meanings.
- **Contextual Meaning**: Understanding word meanings based on passage context.
- **Idioms & Phrasal Verbs**: Common expressions and their meanings.

#### **Key Words & Synonyms from the Passage:**
| Word          | Synonym (from options) | Meaning                          |
|---------------|------------------------|----------------------------------|
| Ridicule      | Contempt (A)           | Mockery or disrespect            |
| Repulsive     | Distaste (A)           | Causing strong dislike           |
| Impulsive     | -                      | Acting without thought           |
| Repealed      | Revoked (B)            | Officially canceled/replaced     |
| Reliable      | Dependable (B)         | Trustworthy                      |
| Repellent     | Objectionable (B)      | Unpleasant or offensive          |
| Whim          | Caprice (D)            | Sudden/unpredictable change      |
| Warmth        | Cordiality (E)         | Friendliness                     |
| Welt          | Bruise (A)             | A mark/injury on the skin         |
| Wage          | Compensation (C)       | Payment for work                 |
| Wilt          | Shrivel (B)            | To wither or dry up              |

#### **Idioms & Phrasal Verbs:**
| Phrase/Idiom          | Meaning                                  |
|-----------------------|------------------------------------------|
| Rule out               | Eliminate a possibility (Q22)           |
| Hear on the grapevine  | Hear a rumor (Q23)                      |
| All Greek to me        | Difficult to understand (Q38)           |
| Get around             | Move or travel (e.g., in a wheelchair) (Q39) |
| Look up                | Search for information (Q31)             |
| Literally              | In a strict sense (non-figurative) (Q40) |

---

### **2. Grammar**
#### **Core Concepts:**
- **Parts of Speech**: Identifying nouns, pronouns, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, etc.
- **Articles**: Correct usage of *a*, *an*, *the*, or none.
- **Subject-Verb Agreement**: Singular/plural verb forms.
- **Modals**: *Shall*, *will*, *may*, *can/cannot* (ability, permission, prohibition).
- **Pronouns**: Identifying types (e.g., *he* as a subject pronoun in Q28).

#### **Key Rules & Examples:**
| Concept               | Rule/Example                                                                 |
|-----------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Adjectives**        | Formed from nouns (e.g., *hope* → *hopeful* (Q26)).                         |
| **Adverbs**           | Modifies verbs (e.g., *now* in "The movie is starting **now**" (Q25)).       |
| **Articles**          | - *A* before consonants (Q29: "in **a** hurry").                          |
|                       | - *The* for specific nouns (Q30: "play **the** guitar").                     |
| **Subject-Verb Agreement** | Singular subjects take singular verbs (Q27: "Information **is** misleading"). |
| **Modals**            | - *Will* for offers/invitations (Q24: "**Will** you play with us?").        |
|                       | - *Can’t* for inability (Q41: "I **can’t** swim" → inability).              |
| **Pronouns**          | *He* is a subject pronoun (Q28: "**He** is the best player").               |

---

### **3. Reading Comprehension**
#### **Core Skills:**
- **Main Idea**: Identifying the central theme of a passage (e.g., Wright brothers' perseverance).
- **Inference**: Drawing conclusions from implied information.
- **Vocabulary in Context**: Understanding words like *repellent*, *compulsion*, *impelled*.
- **Contrast/Transition Words**: Identifying words like *however* (Q3) to show contrast.

#### **Passage Summary (Wright Brothers):**
- **Theme**: Perseverance in innovation despite ridicule.
- **Key Events**:
  1. First powered flight (1903) met with skepticism.
  2. Wright brothers' early interest in mechanics (kites, toys, printing press).
  3. Rejection of Lilienthal’s body-shifting method for gliders.
  4. Wind tunnel experiments to correct air pressure data.
  5. Invention of the first airplane (<$1000).
- **Vocabulary Highlights**:
  - *Impelled*: Driven by desire.
  - *Compulsion*: Strong urge.
  - *Repealed*: Replaced (old air pressure tables).

---

### **4. Phonetics & Pronunciation**
#### **Core Concepts:**
- **Vowel Sounds**:
  - Monophthongs (single sounds: /u/ in *hook* (Q32)).
  - Diphthongs (double sounds: absent in *stew* (Q34)).
- **Semi-Vowels**: /y/ (e.g., transition in "She advised" (Q35)).
- **Pause**: Acts as punctuation in speech (Q36: True).
- **Long/Short Vowels**: *Blast* has a long vowel (Q33).

#### **Key Examples:**
| Sound Type       | Example Words                     | Notes                                  |
|------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| **/u/ sound**    | *Hook* (Q32)                      | Not in *soon* or *boon* (diphthongs).  |
| **Diphthong**    | *Loiter*, *maiden* (Q34)          | *Stew* is a monophthong.               |
| **Semi-Vowel**   | /y/ in "She advised" (Q35)        | Transition between words.             |
| **Long Vowel**   | *Blast* (Q33)                     | Contrast with short vowels (e.g., *bat*). |

---

### **5. Communication Skills (Telephonic Conversation)**
#### **Core Concepts:**
- **Filling Blanks**: Appropriate responses in dialogues (Q17–Q21).
- **Politeness**: Using formal language (e.g., *ma’am*, *please*).
- **Clarity**: Confirming audio quality, purpose of call.

#### **Dialogue Structure (Q17–Q21):**
1. **Introduction**:
   - *"Who is calling, please?"* (Q17).
2. **Audio Issue**:
   - *"The audio was not clear."* (Q18).
3. **Purpose**:
   - *"How may I help you?"* (Q19).
4. **Scheduling**:
   - *"Will you be free in [slot]?"* (Q20).
5. **Closing**:
   - *"Is there anything else?"* (Q21).

---

### **6. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Vocabulary & Synonyms**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Vocabulary] --> B[Synonyms]
    A --> C[Antonyms]
    A --> D[Contextual Meaning]
    B --> E[Ridicule-Contempt]
    B --> F[Repulsive-Distaste]
    B --> G[Repealed-Revoked]
    C --> H[Impulsive-Opposite: Thoughtful]
    D --> I[Repellent in Passage]
    D --> J[Whim-Caprice]
```

#### **Graph 2: Grammar Concepts**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Parts of Speech]
    A --> C[Articles]
    A --> D[Subject-Verb Agreement]
    A --> E[Modals]
    B --> F[Nouns]
    B --> G[Pronouns]
    B --> H[Adjectives/Adverbs]
    C --> I[A/An/The]
    D --> J[Singular-Plural Verbs]
    E --> K[Will-Shall-May]
    E --> L[Can't-Inability]
```

#### **Graph 3: Phonetics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Phonetics] --> B[Vowel Sounds]
    A --> C[Diphthongs]
    A --> D[Semi-Vowels]
    A --> E[Pause]
    B --> F[Monophthongs: /u/ in Hook]
    B --> G[Long Vowel: Blast]
    C --> H[Loiter-Maiden]
    C --> I[Stew-No Diphthong]
    D --> J[/y/ in She advised]
    E --> K[Pause as Punctuation]
```

#### **Graph 4: Reading Comprehension**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Main Idea]
    A --> C[Inference]
    A --> D[Vocabulary in Context]
    A --> E[Contrast Words]
    B --> F[Wright Brothers' Perseverance]
    C --> G[Impelled = Driven]
    D --> H[Repellent-Objectionable]
    E --> I[However = Contrast]
```

#### **Graph 5: Communication Skills**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Telephonic Conversation] --> B[Introduction]
    A --> C[Audio Check]
    A --> D[Purpose]
    A --> E[Scheduling]
    A --> F[Closing]
    B --> G[Who is calling?]
    C --> H[Audio not clear]
    D --> I[How may I help?]
    E --> J[Free in slot?]
    F --> K[Anything else?]
```

---
### **Exam Preparation Tips**
1. **Vocabulary**: Memorize synonyms/antonyms (focus on passage words).
2. **Grammar**:
   - Practice subject-verb agreement (singular/plural).
   - Review modals (*will* for offers, *can’t* for inability).
3. **Phonetics**: Distinguish monophthongs vs. diphthongs (e.g., *hook* vs. *soon*).
4. **Reading**: Skim passages for main ideas; note contrast words (*however*).
5. **Communication**: Use formal phrases for telephonic conversations.
